Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Gender, Race, and Identity Development in Black Youth

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

This collaborative project aims to study the effects of personal and group identity variables on STEM educational outcomes. Longitudinal data will be collected and analyzed on a number of self and other motivational variables to understand how these personal and social factors are likely to determine the educational trajectories and decisions of African-American youth. Little research, though, has addressed developmental changes in stereotype awareness and endorsement, or ramifications of stereotypes and discrimination for identity development and achievement striving in Black adolescents. The proposed study will model the relationship of two salient group memberships, race and gender, with achievement outcomes for Black youth. Prior research has underscored the need to attend to race and gender simultaneously, as well as the importance of evaluating motivational and achievement outcomes within academic domains (e.g., English and science).
The proposed study is an extension and expansion of a previous NSF-funded longitudinal study of African American youth. The goal of this follow-up study is to concentrate more explicitly on the simultaneous effects of race-related and gender-related experiences and beliefs and on investigating how these experiences play out across different course content domains (e.g., English, science, and mathematics). Using survey and qualitative methods, the study will describe normative development in self-concept, stereotypes, motivation, and parenting from fifth through twelfth grade. Another important goal of the project is to determine whether the advantages gained by girls in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) areas are maintained as they prepare to move through more advanced coursework and college applications, and what personal, family, and school context factors predict STEM interest and success for both genders. The proposed outcomes will aid in the understanding of how self-concept and other self variables impacts motivation as a predictor for success in STEM disciplines which may in turn broaden participation of under represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this study was to examine the ways that race and gender stereotypes about academic abilities change from fifth to twelfth grade and the implications of those stereotypes for youths’ academic motivation.  We were also interested in ways in which other aspects of identity (e.g., perceptions of competence; racial identity; gender identity) shape youths’ well-being and ways in which parents influence these processes. We began with a sample of about 350 African American fifth graders and their parents and teachers, interviewing them a second time in Grade 7. When youth were in Grade 10 we added a sample of about 600 additional African American and European American youth and parents, following the entire sample to youth’s Grade 12 year.

A first goal was to assess how race and gender academic stereotypes change across time.  On average, the Black students in our sample endorsed both race and gender academic stereotypes. Whites were viewed as more competent than Blacks across all academic domains.  Interestingly, girls were rated as more competent than boys in math, science, and English, although boys tended to view boys as more capable—particularly in math and science—than girls viewed them. Whereas students' ratings of the academic competence of Whites did not change from Grade 7 to Grade 10, ratings of the academic competence of Blacks dropped across those three years. The magnitude of gender academic stereotypes did not change from Grade 7 to Grade 10 (Skinner et al., 2011).

Race stereotypes had important implications for students’ academic self-perceptions.  We showed that Black seventh graders’ race stereotypes were related to their perceptions of their own academic abilities.  When youth believed that Blacks tend to do less well in schools than Whites, they tended to view their own performance more negatively, even after we accounted for their actual achievement.  We found that this effect was strongest when youth reported that their racial identity was very important to their sense of self (Okeke, Howard, Kurtz-Costes, & Rowley, 2009).

We also found that race and gender stereotypes do not affect all students in the same manner.  Although Black boys’ self-concepts were related to their endorsement of both race and gender stereotypes, Black girls’ self-concepts were more closely related to their gender stereotypes than to their beliefs about race differences in academic abilities (Evans, Copping, Rowley, & Kurtz-Costes, 2011).  We believe that Black boys view themselves as embodying both race and gender stereotypes, whereas Black girls are more identified with their gender within the school setting. 

We also studied parent stereotypes.  On average, the African American mothers in our sample viewed girls as more competent than boys academically. Moreover, mothers’ endorsement of this gender stereotype was related both to their perceptions of their own child’s ability and their expectations for their own children’s eventual educational attainment with children’s actual achievement controlled (Wood, Kurtz-Costes, Rowley, & Okeke, 2010). Mothers who viewed boys as less competent than girls academically—regardless of their children’s current levels of academic achievement—had lower educational expectations of their sons, and higher educational expectations of their daughters than did parents with more gender egalitarian beliefs. Our results imply that negative beliefs about the school achievement of African American boys may create a “negative feedback loop” that perpetuates the underachievement of Black boys.
